title: I’m a minister who got arrested for taking part in Extinction Rebellion protests
text:
As a minister, people tend to expect that you will be law-abiding, so as I return to the ‘day job’ I will have some explaining to do (Picture: Paul Rand)

I’m an ordained minister in the Methodist Church and on Monday morning, I was carried off Lambeth Bridge by four police constables for ‘wilful obstruction of the highway’.

It happened during an Extinction Rebellion protest – my arresting officer said he’d never nicked a ‘vicar’ before.

I spent a little over 20 hours in custody, most of it in a police cell in Lewisham. It’s the first time I’ve done anything more dramatic than join the odd protest march, and certainly the first time I’ve been arrested.

Strangely, I felt totally at peace the entire time. I experienced a clear sense of call from God to be there, so I felt I had nothing to fear.

As a minister, people tend to expect that you will be law-abiding, so as I return to the ‘day job’ I will have some explaining to do! It’s no surprise that some disapprove of my actions, but I have also had huge support from Christians and others.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The Church has become so much a part of the establishment that people can easily forget that there is a great tradition of people of faith speaking truth to power, even when there is a personal cost.

I am a newcomer to XR – although I’ve done my background reading, I’ve not managed to attend any groups or training.

This week is the first active involvement I’ve had, through Christian Climate Action (CCA), one of the faith groups participating in the protests.

I have been extremely impressed by the XR ethos – emphatically non-violent, listening, non-hierarchical, relationship-building – and it’s amazing to see how successfully this culture has been built in a rapidly expanding and diverse movement.

To me, all this seems to be consonant with what the church ought to be, but often struggles with.

I, like many others, have tried writing letters, signing petitions and speaking to my MP, but not enough is being done

At heart, my reason for participating is because I believe we are in an emergency situation.

The train is hurtling towards a climate crisis and we need to pull the red alarm handle. XR is trying to raise the alarm, but the driver doesn’t seem to be listening.

I, like many others, have tried writing letters, signing petitions and speaking to my MP, but not enough is being done. People criticise XR’s tactics and say that disrupting people’s lives isn’t the right way to go about it, but history shows us that non-violent direct action does bring change.

Advertisement

Advertisement

That red handle on the train says ‘penalty for improper use’. If we pulled the handle because someone spilled their coffee, we would rightly be in trouble because it’s something we can manage on our own. This is more than a mere coffee spill.

For years now the message seems to have been that we all just need to adjust our habits a little bit; turn the heating down a degree, recycle rubbish, swap the car for public transport a little more often. These things are all good and necessary, but they simply cannot address an emergency of this scale.

It is far beyond being dealt with by individual consumer choices, regardless of how many of us are on message.

I recognise that the police have a job to do, but there have been questions about the lawfulness of some of the actions taken, such as confiscating disability equipment, and now the latest development in banning all protests in London. The right to peaceful protest is protected under the European Convention of Human Rights.

I’m also sorry for those who have been inconvenienced by XR’s actions, but this emergency is bigger than our personal needs.

The effects of the climate crisis have already brought huge disruption, including in Cumbria, where I live and work. Bridges and roads aren’t blocked by protesters, but have instead been washed away, leaving some communities with 40-mile detours for months on end.

Advertisement

These events are becoming more frequent.

It will get worse, and those who are poorest will suffer the most, particularly in developing countries. I cannot stand by while injustice grows.

I don’t know what the penalty for pulling the red handle will be for me, but I believe I took a measured and proportionate action in the face of an emergency.

We need the driver to stop the train.

The Revd Jo Rand is a Methodist Minister serving in Cumbria.
